children.html: LIVE EVENT: This Monday 8/22 at 7pm ET (4pm PT) on our weekly Callin show Lever Live, David Sirota will be joined by special guest Adam McKay, the Academy Award-winning writer and director of The Big Short and Vice. David and Adam will be answering questions from the audience live on-air about living through the past year of U.S. politics, which has felt eerily similar to the Oscar-nominated disaster movie they co-wrote, Don’t Look Up.

children.text: Good things are happening! In California, fast food workers are nearing the finish line in a long fight to transform workplace conditions for hundreds of thousands of employees. Talk about solidarity! Meanwhile, Boston is pushing to eliminate fossil fuels from new construction, while a judge has halted coal leases on federal lands. Also, Trader Joe’s and Amazon workers are making progress on new union drives, and nurses in Minnesota are going on strike by the thousands.
All this and much more in this week’s edition of
You Love To See It
, exclusively for supporting subscribers.

children.html: This is an excerpt from today’s edition of You Love To See It — a weekly feature reviewing good news, progress and action steps for supporting subscriber. To read the entire article and access all of our subscriber-only content, click here or below to become a supporting subscriber of The Lever for $8 a month or $70 a year. When you subscribe, you are helping us do this reporting and hire more journalists.

children.text: California Could Transform The Fast Food Industry For Workers
California state senators will vote on the
Fast Food Accountability and Standards Recovery (FAST) Act
this month. The FAST Act would
establish

a new state council to create minimum working standards for fast food restaurants. It would also have the power to hold companies like McDonald’s and Burger King accountable for their franchisees’ labor violations like wage theft and sexual harassment — the sort of liability that franchises
usually
get to avoid.
There are over 500,000
fast food workers
in California, two-thirds of whom are women and sixty percent of whom are Latinx. “There may be no more consequential measure for labor rights in Sacramento this session,”
wrote
LA Times
columnist Michael Hiltzik.
Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and Fight for $15 have
organized
more than
one hundred

organizations and unions in support of the legislation. Already, five city and county governments, including those of Los Angeles and San Francisco, have also come out in support of the act. This Twitter
thread
breaks down how long people have been fighting to get to this point. Some workers are
even
sleeping at the state capitol to demand action.
You can read about how the FAST Recovery Act would be a huge step toward broad-based bargaining
here
, and you can help demand action in solidarity with workers
here
Boston Wants To Ban Fossil Fuels For New Buildings
Days after Governor Charlie Baker
announced
a new climate
law
enabling ten Massachusetts cities and towns to ban fossil fuels in new buildings, Boston
stepped up
to the plate to join the program. If the effort moves forward, Boston would join
New York City
San Jose
Seattle
, and
Washington D.C.
in enacting such a ban. According to Boston emissions
data
, commercial, industrial, and residential buildings generated 70 percent of emissions in 2019, so Boston’s commitment to a ban could deliver real change.
“Our city is ready to join this pilot program to understand and lay out how banning new fossil fuel hookups can benefit our cities, our state, and our country,” Mayor Michelle Wu
announced
at a news conference on Tuesday.
Coal Leasing Halted On Federal Lands
A federal judge in Montana
ordered
the Bureau of Land
Management to halt new coal leases on all federal lands, reinstating a ban repealed by the Trump administration in 2017.

U.S. District Judge Brian Morris found that the Trump administration’s review of coal sales inadequately considered coal’s impact on climate, violating the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). Almost
half

of the country’s yearly coal supply is mined by private companies exploiting public, federally leased lands. Maintaining a NEPA review process that actually considers the impact of coal on climate is necessary to limit the power of coal companies.

children.text: Minnesota Nurses Go On Strike
As thousands of behavioral health care workers go on
strike
in California, 15,000 nurses with the Minnesota Nurses Association voted to
strike
for fair contracts and demand that patients be prioritized above profits.

“Hospital executives with million-dollar salaries have created a crisis of retention and care in our healthcare system, as more nurses are leaving the bedside, putting quality patient care at risk,” said Mary C. Turner, a registered nurse at North Memorial Hospital, in the union’s
statement
. “Nurses do not take this decision lightly, but we are determined to take a stand at the bargaining table, and on the sidewalk if necessary, to put patients before profits in our hospitals.”
Trader Joe’s And Amazon Unionization Momentum
Late last week, a Trader Joe’s store in Minneapolis became the second of the grocery chain’s five hundred-plus locations to
unionize

. Meanwhile, workers at a store in Boulder, Colorado, are poised to push for a third. Looking at organizing efforts across the country at companies like Starbucks, Sarah Beth Ryther, a worker at the Minneapolis Trader Joe’s,
told
Vox
, “We really and truly are interested in creating a larger movement because we are all going through the same things.”
On Tuesday, near Albany, Amazon workers
filed
to form a union with the National Labor Relations Board, making it the
fifth
warehouse location to do so. Lead organizer Heather Goodall told the
Albany Proper
“We won’t stop until Amazon listens. They are eventually going to have to concede.”
In Other Good News…
Councilmember Looks To Recreate Barcelona’s “Superblocks” In Los Angeles
Urbanize Los Angeles)
FDA Finalizes Historic Rule Enabling Access To Over-the-Counter Hearing Aids For Millions Of Americans
FDA News Release)
Presbyterians Agree To Divest From Fossil Fuel Companies
(Projin News)
Duke University Press Workers Officially Win Union
Duke Chronicle)
Finally…
After all the news this week, take a moment to read Tracy K. Smith’s poem on the future, “
Sci-Fi
There will be no edges, but curves.
Clean lines pointing only forward.
History, with its hard spine & dog-eared
Corners, will be replaced with nuance,
Just like the dinosaurs gave way
To mounds and mounds of ice.
Women will still be women, but
The distinction will be empty. Sex,
Having outlived every threat, will gratify
Only the mind, which is where it will exist.
For kicks, we’ll dance for ourselves
Before mirrors studded with golden bulbs.
The oldest among us will recognize that glow—
But the word sun will have been re-assigned
To the Standard Uranium-Neutralizing device
Found in households and nursing homes.
And yes, we’ll live to be much older, thanks
To popular consensus. Weightless, unhinged,
Eons from even our own moon, we’ll drift
In the haze of space, which will be, once
And for all, scrutable and safe.
Our news organization relies on readers pitching in to support our journalism.
If you like this story, please support
our
work.
